title-group.article-title: Concentration of torsional shear stresses in axisymmetric bars with deep periodic grooves

contrib-group.aff: Dipartimento di Scienze e Metodi dell’Ingegneria, Università di Modena e Reggio Emilia, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Davide Castagnetti, Dipartimento di Scienze e Metodi dell’Ingegneria, Università di Modena e Reggio Emilia, Via Amendola 2 - 42100 Reggio Emilia, Italy. Email: davide.castagnetti@unimore.it

abstract.p: The torsional stresses in round bars with deep periodic grooves are calculated by means of the formal analogy between the elastic problem and an auxiliary thermal problem. The analogy allows demanding three-dimensional analyses to be replaced with light two-dimensional analyses, easily implemented on general-purpose finite element packages. Following Neuber’s equivalence concept, the stress concentration in each periodically grooved bar is independently calculated by referring to a single groove of like geometry but lesser depth. Neuber’s approach predicts very closely the reference numerical results if supplemented with a heuristic depth correction function formerly developed by the authors for shallow periodic notches under torsion.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A notch whose profile repeats itself every given length along a solid is called periodic. Instances of periodic notches in mechanical design are threaded profiles, splined shafts, labyrinth grooves, toothed gears, perforated plates, and many others.1 In his seminal book on notch stress theory,2 Neuber suggests a unique method for calculating the stress concentration factor in periodic notches (Figure 1). The periodic notch is likened to a single notch of similar shape and lower depth. The reduced depth, t*, is obtained from the depth, t, of the periodic notch times a depth reduction factor γ, namely t* = γ t. Neuber demonstrated that the depth reduction factor depends only on the ratio t/P between depth and pitch of the original notch (Figure 2, curve a) according to the function γ = (P/π t) tanh(π t/P).

caption.p: Symbolic equivalence between periodic notch and single notch with equal maximum stresses.
Alternative curves for the depth reduction factor γ as a function of the depth to pitch ratio t/P.

sec.p: This criterion was developed analytically by Neuber under the strict conditions of sharp shallow notches at the edge of a half plane undergoing edge-wise, out-of-plane shear stresses. However, Neuber himself and other authors3 have inferred the applicability of the criterion to periodic notches of any proportion (also rounded and deep) subjected to any stress condition (shear and normal stresses as well). From a practical standpoint, this conceptual extension allows the wealth of data available for the single notches4,5 to be transferred to the far less explored family of periodic notches.

Unfortunately, the indiscriminate application of Neuber’s criterion to whatever notch geometry can lead to poor results. Take, for instance, the half-plane with equispaced semicircular edge notches at a distance of 2.5 times the radius (t/P = 0.4), subjected to edge-wise in-plane tension. For this case, Neuber’s procedure predicts a stress concentration factor of 2.7, in excess of 50% over the exact value of 1.8.6 In recent investigations,7,8 the authors have demonstrated numerically that Neuber’s method is accurate only under the underlying assumptions postulated in the theory (sharp shallow notch under shear stresses). For the geometries and loading conditions more likely to be encountered in practice (rounded, deep notch under either shear or normal stresses9), the method largely overestimates the stress concentration. Errors up to 100% of the true value have been detected both in grooved bars under normal stresses7 and in splined profiles under shear stresses.8

However, the previous research has also shown that Neuber’s correspondence concept can be repaired heuristically by changing the function for the depth reduction factor γ. For a wide range of periodic notches under normal stresses, Dragoni and Castagnetti7 propose the function γ = (P/3π t) tanh(3π t/P) (Figure 2, curve b). For shallow periodic notches under shear stresses, Dragoni and Castagnetti8 disclose the following form (Figure 2, curve c)

Function (1) was developed for U-shaped blunt notches at the edge of a twisted bar with infinite diameter (shallow notches). In order to test the generality of this function for periodic notches under shear stresses in general, the present paper extends the work of Dragoni and Castagnetti8 to twisted finite-diameter round bars with deep U-shaped grooves as shown in Figure 3.

sec.p: The analyses are carried out numerically exploiting an insightful thermal-elastic analogy which substitutes a light two-dimensional (2D) steady-state thermal problem for the heavy three-dimensional (3D) elastostatic torsion problem. Together with the enlargement of the geometries with respect to Dragoni and Castagnetti8 the thermal reintepretation of the electric analogy and its numerical (rather than experimental) implementation, represent a novelty of this paper.

In the following two sections, the thermal-elastic analogy is first presented in general terms, then it is applied to the periodically grooved bar shown in Figure 3. A third section with summary and discussion of the results closes the paper.

sec.title: Thermal analogy
sec.p: The numerical approach to the elastic problem tackled in this paper exploits the formal analogy between the torsion of an axisymmetric solid and the steady-state heat flux in a flat plate with variable thickness. This section is devoted to understanding the thermal-elastic analogy in formal terms.

sec.p: This thermal analogy is a variant of the electric analogy, a cumbersome experimental technique which has been used long ago to solve torsional problems by working on physical models.12–14 The thermal version of the analogy, although useless experimentally, is very easily implemented numerically by means of finite element (FE) packages as will be shown in the following section.

sec.title: Geometries
sec.p: The geometries investigated are shown in Figures 4 and 5, with Figure 4 identifying a specific single-groove bar and Figure 5 defining parametrically a family of periodically grooved bars.

caption.p: Detailed geometry of an axial section of the single-groove bar used for numerical validation.
Parametric geometry of an axial section of the periodically grooved bar analysed systematically.

sec.p: The bar with the single semicircular groove in Figure 4 was used as a benchmark for the thermal analogy method. The stress results from the analogy were compared with the theoretical solution available in the literature15–17 and with the outcome of a conventional 3D FE analysis. This step of the analysis allowed the accuracy and the efficiency of the thermal method to be assessed against established results and procedures.

The bar with periodic U-grooves in Figure 5 was analysed systematically with the 2D thermal method only. The investigation examined all the 156 geometries obtained from Figure 5 by varying the ratio ρ/t from 0.2 to 1 with step 0.2, the ratio t/P from 0 (single notch) with step 0.1 up to a maximum of 2 and the ratio d/ρ in the set 5, 25, 100. Combination of these parameters gives a ratio d/t spanning from 1 to 100, thus covering the full range of geometries from very deep to relatively shallow notches (achieved when ρ/t = 1 and d/t = 100, according to Noda and Takase16). This step of the analysis represents the core of the paper, aimed at evaluating the stress concentration effect of the general periodic geometry.

sec.title: Stress analysis
sec.p: The 3D FE analysis of the single-groove bar in Figure 4 was performed with the CosmosWorks package. The full 3D solid was discretized with a mesh of 300,194 4-noded, quadratic-interpolation tetrahedral elements, giving a total of 1,345,992 degrees of freedom. Elastic material behaviour was assumed with Young’s modulus = 206,000 MPa and Poisson’s ratio = 0.3. The torsional loading was enforced by restraining one end face of the model and applying a unit torsional moment to the other end using the remote load option.

The 2D thermal analyses of the bars in Figures 4 and 5 were performed with the FE LUSAS package (version 13.4). For symmetry reasons, the models were restricted to the etched domains ABCDE, with applied constant temperature on the sides AB and CD, and perfect thermal insulation along BC and AED. The domains were discretized using 8-noded, quadratic interpolation, thermal quadrilaterals with a mesh density (average element side length) similar to that adopted in the 3D elastostatic model. The thickness of the models was assumed to vary with cubic law from the side BC (zero thickness) towards the edge AED. The thermal conductivity was arbitrarily set to c = 1 W/(m·K) so that the heat flux density ( c·t/s) provided by LUSAS as standard output variable coincided numerically with the thermal gradient needed in the equation for the stress concentration factor (see below).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the contour maps of characteristic results obtained numerically for the grooved bars. Figure 6(a) displays the shear stresses in the 3D FE model of the single-groove bar from Figure 4. Figures 6(b) and (c) display the distribution of the temperature gradient in the 2D thermal models for the single-groove bar (Figure 4) and the periodic-groove bar (Figure 5), respectively. All the models analysed presented the maximum stresses at the bottom of the grooves (point A in Figures 4 and 5) as shown in Figure 6(a) and (b).

caption.p: Plot of shear stresses in the single-groove bar provided by the 3D finite element model (a); temperature gradient provided by the 2D thermal model in the single-groove (b) and periodic-groove bar (c).

sec.p: For the benchmark single-groove bar in Figure 4, the thermal model (Figure 6(b)) gave a stress concentration factor Kt = 1.4923, whereas the 3D FE model (Figure 6(a)) predicted the value Kt = 1.4931. Several solutions for the theoretical stress concentration factor can be retrieved from the literature for the same geometry: Nisitani and Noda provide Kt = 1.4892,17 the procedure in Appendix 215 gives the value Kt = 1.491, while a more recent theoretical solution by Zappalorto et al.18 obtains Kt = 1.452. An accurate comparison among data from different sources is drawn in a paper by Hasegawa and Kuriyama,19 including also data from Matthews and Hooke.20

The theoretical stress concentration factor for the same geometry is Kt = 1.4892 and the procedure in Appendix 215 gives the value Kt = 1.491. Although comparable in terms of accuracy, with respect to the 3D FE model, the 2D thermal analogy model proved much easier to implement and quicker to execute. The application of the boundary conditions, especially those enforcing symmetry, was very straightforward in the thermal model and much trickier in the elastostatic model. The central processing unit (CPU) time consumed for the thermal analysis was 3 s, against 610 s for the FE analysis on the same computer.

The entire set of stress concentration factors calculated thermally for the periodically notched bar in Figure 5 are displayed in Figure 7 (black circles). For each combination of dimensionless variables (ρ/t, t/P and d/ρ), the prediction of the stress concentration obtained using Neuber’s method is also provided (hollow circles). Neuber’s predictions were obtained from Kato’s equation15 for the twisted bar with single U-groove summarized in Appendix 2. At any occurrence, the depth t in Kato’s equation was replaced with the reduced depth t* = γ t, with γ given by (1). For example, assume a periodic U-notch defined by depth t = 0.5, pitch P = 1.25, root diameter d = 5 and a fillet radius ρ = 0.2 . For t/P = 0.5/1.25 = 0.4 equation (1) gives the depth reduction factor γ = 0.3927, from which the reduced depth t* = γ t = 0.3927 × 0.5 = 0.1963 is calculated. By substituting t* for t, Appendix 2 gives sequentially A = 7.5670, B = 0.8709 and k0 = 1.9898, which result in the stress concentration factor Kts = 1.7189 for the equivalent single groove. The large bulk of theoretical stress concentration factors presented in Figure 7 can be used in combination with the closed-form stress distributions for (single and inclined) deep notches under torsion reported by Zappalorto and Lazzarin21 that change as a function of Kt.

caption.p: Comparison of results for the periodic stress concentration factor in the periodically notched bar.

sec.p: The numerical stress concentration factors in Figure 7 corresponding to periodic notches with the highest value of d/t ( = 100, combination of d/ρ = 100 and ρ/t = 1) compare favourably with those obtained by Dragoni and Castagnetti8 for the torsion of prismatic bars with shallow (d/t ≥ 1000) periodic U-notches of equal profile. The maximum difference between the two cases is about 3% with respect to the results from Dragoni and Castagnetti.8

The error of the predicted results in Figure 7 with respect to the (exact) numerical values is lower than 4% over the entire range of geometries explored. Use of Neuber’s original depth reduction factor γ = (P/π t) tanh(π t/P) would give errors up to 20%. Considering the good agreement disclosed by Dragoni and Castagnetti8 for a different class of notches, equation (1) can be regarded as a general (though heuristic) equivalence link between periodic and single notch under shear stresses.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The formal analogy between the elastic torsion of axisymmetric solids and the steady-state heat flow in a planar plate was used to calculate accurately and efficiently the stress concentrations in circular bars with deep periodic U-grooves. The results were used to benchmark Neuber’s equivalence concept, according to which the maximum stress for the periodic notch is calculated in an equivalent single notch of like geometry and lower depth. When combined with a heuristic depth correction function formerly developed by the authors for a different class of periodic notches under torsion, Neuber’s approach predicted very closely the reference numerical results.
